The proof is based loosely on two ideas:
We may compare the factorization of x^{n}-1 over \mathbb {Q} with that of x^{n}-1 over \mathbb {F}_{p} with p\nmid n.
Investigate how automorphisms of a finite field permute the roots of polynomials. More about the second idea: suppose F(x) is a polynomial over \mathbb {F}_{p} and F(x)=f(x)g(x) for some f(x),g(x)\in \mathbb {F}_{p}[x]. The splitting field of F(x) is \mathbb {F}_{p^{n}} for some n, and the Frobenius morphism \phi (x)=x^{p} is an automorphism of this splitting field. Since \phi is the identity function on \mathbb {F}_{p}, it must permute the roots of F(x). Suppose \alpha is a root of F(x). Then \phi (\alpha )=\alpha ^{p} is a root of either f(x) or g(x). But g(\alpha ^{p})=g(\alpha )^{p}, so g(\alpha ^{p})=0 implies g(\alpha )=0. So if F(x) is separable, then the Frobenius morphism permutes the roots of different factors of F(x) separately.
Studying how automorphisms of a splitting field for a polynomial acts on the roots of the polynomial naturally leads to Galois theory.
